hypotheses: Regular religious service attendees have more favorable religious views and are more likely to align with traditional religio-scientific perspectives.
Religiously unaffiliated respondents will be more likely to favor science and align with the modern perspective.
Women, on average, will have more favorable views of religion and may be less scientifically oriented due to socialization.
Racial and ethnic minorities will display less favorable scientific perspectives relative to whites.
Higher education will correlate with pro-science and less religious (modern) views.

data.notes: Analysis uses a set of attitude items and 14 quiz-style scientific knowledge questions; measures include 4-point attitude scales; pooled cross-sectional data from specified GSS waves; no specific dataset link or file-format notes provided in the paper summary.

method.description: The authors use latent class analysis (LCA) on GSS items measuring scientific knowledge, attitudes toward science, and religious beliefs to identify latent religio-scientific perspective classes. They compare fit statistics (BIC, Lo-Mendell-Rubin test) across models and select a three-class solution based on fit and theoretical interpretability. After classifying respondents into latent classes (traditional, modern, post-secular), they examine sociodemographic correlates using multinomial logistic regression and assess associations between class membership and political/policy attitudes (e.g., abortion, stem cell research) using regression models. Analyses use Mplus for LCA and Stata for subsequent regressions.
steps: Obtain and pool GSS waves 2006, 2008, and 2010 and select relevant items (science knowledge quiz items, science attitude items, religious belief indicators, sociodemographics, and policy attitude items).
Prepare manifest indicators: code 14 scientific knowledge items, scale science attitude items (4-point scales), and code religious belief items (Bible belief, creation/evolution items, etc.).

Estimate latent class models in Mplus varying number of classes (e.g., 2–6), evaluate model fit using BIC and the Lo-Mendell-Rubin (LMR) likelihood-ratio test, and inspect manifest response probabilities.

Select a theoretically and empirically defensible model (authors choose a three-class model despite BIC preference for more classes), label classes (traditional, modern, post-secular) based on item-response patterns.
Assign class membership probabilities or most likely class for respondents.

Estimate multinomial logistic regressions (in Stata) predicting class membership from sociodemographic covariates (religious tradition, attendance, gender, race, education, political ideology, occupational status, age, geography).
Estimate logistic/multinomial regressions of policy attitudes (abortion rights, stem cell research funding, GM food opinions, etc.) on class membership and controls to assess political implications.
Interpret results, report descriptive item-response probabilities, class prevalences, regression coefficients, chi-squared tests, and significance tests.
method.models: Latent Class Analysis (LCA) to identify latent groups; model selection using BIC and Lo-Mendell-Rubin LRT; Multinomial logistic regression predicting class membership; logistic/linear regressions of policy outcomes on class membership and covariates.
method.outcome_variable: Primary: latent class membership (traditional, modern, post-secular). Secondary outcomes in policy analyses: support for abortion rights, support for public funding of stem cell research, attitudes toward genetically modified food, opinions on fuel economy standards, and nuclear energy.
method.independent_variables: Manifest indicators for LCA: scientific knowledge quiz items (14 items), science attitudes (multiple 4-point items), religious belief indicators (Bible belief, creation/evolution responses). In regression models: religious tradition, religious attendance, gender, race, education, occupational status, age, geography, political ideology, and class membership (for policy regressions).
method.control_variables: Sociodemographic controls used in regressions: race, education, religious attendance, political ideology, gender, age, geography, occupational status (as reported in the paper summary).
method.tools_software: Mplus (for LCA) and Stata (for multinomial logistic regressions and policy outcome models).

results.summary: Latent class analysis identifies three principal religio-scientific perspectives in the U.S. public: a Traditional class (~43% of respondents) characterized by stronger religious beliefs and lower science literacy; a Modern class (~36%) characterized by high science literacy and low religiosity; and a Post-secular class (~21%) holding favorable views of both science and religion (high science knowledge but religious explanations for some origins). These classes show distinct sociodemographic correlates: religious tradition and attendance, education, race, gender, and political ideology predict class membership. The classes are associated with divergent policy attitudes: moderns generally support abortion rights and stem cell research, while post-seculars are relatively opposed (post-secular opposition to abortion and stem cell research is stronger than traditional opposition in some comparisons). Chi-squared tests and regression analyses show statistically significant associations (e.g., strong association between religious tradition and latent class membership). The authors conclude that public divisions between science and religion are more complex than a simple conflict narrative and that many people integrate both scientific and religious views.
